entry.title: Re: Smart Table with annotation.xml
entry.content:
Hello,

I resolved the issue. I needed to pass my annotations.xml file during the model creation.

        const serviceUri = this.getOwnerComponent()!.getManifestEntry("/sap.app/dataSources").mainService.uri;
        console.log("serviceUri: " + serviceUri);

        const localAnnotationUrl = sap.ui.require.toUrl("dummy3/annotations/annotation0.xml");
        console.log("localAnnoUrl: " + localAnnotationUrl);

        const model = new ODataModel(serviceUri, {
            annotationURI: localAnnotationUrl
        });

entry.title: A Story of Innovation - From Local Beginnings to Global Intelligence with AI-Assisted Insights
entry.content:
How SAPâ€™s Global Business Partner Certificate Management Solution Transforms Compliance

Across industries and regions, businesses face a common challenge â€” managing partner certificates efficiently while meeting strict regulatory requirements.

Different countries enforce unique rules, formats, and audit practices, making it difficult for organizations to stay compliant while operating globally.

Recognizing this growing complexity, SAP teams set out to transform certificate management from a manual, country-specific task into a unified, intelligent global process â€” leading to the creation of the Global Business Partner Certificate Management solution.

A New Chapter for SAP Customers and Partners

This week, SAP hosted a global webinar to introduce this innovation to customers and partners worldwide.
The session brought together SAP experts and business leaders from multiple regions to explore how this new capability helps organizations ensure compliance, simplify operations, and harness AI for smarter insights.

The Business Partner Certificate Management solution empowers SAP S/4HANA customers to centrally maintain and monitor certificates for both suppliers and customers, addressing the end-to-end lifecycle of compliance documentation.

The goal is simple â€” make compliance intelligent, reducing risk and manual effort while enabling businesses to operate seamlessly across borders.

From Regional Beginnings to Global Availability

The journey began with the Supplier Certificate Management solution, first introduced in selected countries across the MENA region and India to manage supplier legal certificates.

Encouraged by strong adoption, customers soon asked a pivotal question:

That feedback sparked a transformation. SAP extended the concept to cover both suppliers and customers, delivering a more comprehensive Business Partner Certificate Management solution that is now available globally across SAP S/4HANA (On-Premise and Private Cloud Edition) â€” with expansion to Public Cloud on the horizon.

Unifying Compliance with Intelligence

The new solution provides a centralized, structured, and auditable way to manage certificates directly within the Business Partner master data.

It supports full lifecycle management â€” including exemptions, extensions, renewals, restorations, and deletions â€” all within SAP S/4HANA.
This ensures that every business partner record remains compliant, current, and ready for audit.

Empowered by SAP Joule

To make the experience even smarter, the solution now integrates with SAP Joule, the AI copilot that delivers AI-assisted insights into certificate management.

Co-Innovation and Customer Feedback

The webinar also showcased real-world use cases â€” from managing trade licenses in the UAE to maintaining minority certificates in the United States â€” and included open dialogue with customers on topics such as Fiori integration, document uploads, tax exemptions, and automation opportunities.

SAP experts emphasized that customer input continues to guide the roadmap â€” with planned enhancements such as automated data extraction from PDFs, email notifications, and deeper integration with SAP Master Data Governance (MDG).

Looking Ahead

The Global Business Partner Certificate Management solution marks a milestone in SAPâ€™s mission to help organizations run compliantly, intelligently, and globally.

By combining automation, AI, and business process integration, SAP is enabling customers to transform certificate management from an operational necessity into a strategic capability â€” one that supports resilience, transparency, and trust across every business partnership.

As one participant summarized it perfectly:

â€œThis is not just a feature â€” itâ€™s a foundation for smarter, compliant business partnerships worldwide.....

Learn more:
Stay tuned to SAP Community for upcoming feature spotlights, customer success stories, and implementation guidance for the Business Partner Certificate Management solution.

Documentation - SAP Help

Blog post - SAP Community

Note 3584385 - SAP for me

Event Page - teams.microsoft

entry.title: Copy of Printout from SAP Going to Wrong Label Printer (Different Plant) when producing material
entry.content:
Hello, 

So i have a very strange problem and will explain the setup below.. 

Plant 1 has 3x Printers and 3x Computers , PC/Printer 1, PC/Printer 2, PC/Printer 3
They all share the same login details User login = User1 for all 3 computers. 

Each printer in Plant 1 has its own IP.
Host Printer = pr1 (not sure what this means?) Group? 
Destination Host = individual IP for each printer

Each material produced has its own setup, different packaging materials, instructions etc... 


Our SAP is setup for multiple plants. 
Plant 1 (my plant)
Plant 2 (receiving a printout of a label created in Plant 1)
Plant 3
Plant 4


We have a production that produces a material in Plant 1.

We use a custom FIORI app to scan the products in the machine, when the UL is met a label is printed next to the machine. 

We have 3 machines, 3 printers and one user login in Plant 1.

The print output is printed in each printer depending on the material / machine (correct)

But everytime the label is printed in Plant 1 there is a copy printed in Plant2 (Only in one printer that has no settings in Plant 1) 
This printer has both Host printer and Destination Host setup as the printers IP. (Ours has pr1 as host printer)

PI for each material has correct settings.
Masterdata for each material has correct settings. 


Nothing indicates to a printer in Plant 2, but there is still a copy being printed in Plant 2, everytime a material is produced.

Doesn't matter if i use a different login, it will still print a label in Plant 2, so it doesn't seem to be account related.

The label printed in Plant 1 has both Storage Unit number 3000xxxxx and "internal HU number" 823xxxx" 


Label printed in Plant 2, doesnt have the internal HU number. 





I appreciate all the ideas and help i could get. 


BR 
Sebastian

entry.title: Re: Planned Depreciation for Following Month Showing Doub...
entry.content:
For a mid year transfer that contains current year depreciation (7205), the system will check that amount for the current year, if it is under or overstated for the current year then an adjustment will be made in the first period after the transfer date. 

I would suggest create a legacy asset on Q with Manage Legacy Assets app with same details as this legacy asset, post the only the opening values, APC and prior year depreciation, then check the asset depreciation tab in the valuation section of the Manage Legacy Assets app, there you can find what should the depreciation be for the months up until transfer. You can also adjust the depreciation settings and do simulation of recalculation.

entry.title: Re: How to auto generate or issue Inventory number for Fi...
entry.content:
The app isn't available in Public Cloud, I'll highlight internally for rewording.
The worklist in Public Cloud is when you open the Manage Fixed Assets app, we would consider this the worklist so no need for another app. 
There can be some restrictions on the fields that are available, like time dependent fields eg cost center, for these we would say you could create a view in the Asset History Sheet for such a requirement if needed.

entry.title: Document Splitting â€“ Overflow Error after Changes in Business Transaction Variant 0000/0001
entry.content:
I have a document splitting issue where additional categories were assigned in the business transaction and transaction variant 0000/0001 for the GRN (Goods Receipt Note) process.

After this, the system started throwing "Document Splitting causes field overflow for currency type Quantity - GLT0004". SAP recommends reverting the configuration to the standard settings, but I am not sure about the impacts of doing so or the best approach to perform this adjustment.

Could anyone please assist or share guidance on how to proceed?

entry.title: PR creation with Ref. to PR
entry.content:
Hi experts, I need a solution for the following scenario:

Before creating a Purchase Requisition (PR), we currently have a manual paper-based  (Demand Approval) approval process for procurement items,  This document contains material details and other related information. After this manual approval, we create the PR in SAP system.

I want this manual document to be created inside SAP, and the PR should be created only with reference to this document , the system should not allow PR creation without this reference.

Can we achieve this without customization, for example, by creating a separate PR document type or through some other standard way? What do you suggest?

entry.title: Setting Up Search for Suppliers in SAP Business Network
entry.content:
Hello everyone, my name is Ashish, and as a product expert for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, I love sharing how you can get the most out of your system. Today, I want to talk about a powerful integration that can fundamentally change how you discover and onboard new suppliers: connecting SAP S/4HANA Cloud with the SAP Business Network.

Are your purchasers spending too much time scouring the internet for new sources of supply? Is it a challenge to vet and verify the capabilities of potential new partners? If so, this integration is for you.

By linking your SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition system directly to the SAP Business Network, you give your purchasing team secure, direct access to a network of more than two million supplier companies. Let's dive into what this means for your business and what the setup journey looks like.

The Power of Connection: Key Features & Benefits

The core purpose of this integration is simple: to make finding and vetting new suppliers faster, easier, and more reliable. Instead of a generic web search, your purchasers get a direct window into a trusted business network, right from their SAP Fiori launchpad.

Here are the standout capabilities this integration unlocks:

  • A Universe of Suppliers at Your Fingertips: Your team can search, filter, and explore profiles on the SAP Business Network. These profiles are rich with detail, describing supplier capabilities, certifications, and even their existing business relationships, offering a level of insight a simple website can't provide.

  • Seamless User Experience with Single Sign-On (SSO): This is the magic that makes it all work smoothly. A purchaser in SAP S/4HANA Cloud can click a tile on their Fiori launchpad and land directly in the SAP Business Network supplier search page without needing to log in again. This frictionless experience encourages adoption and boosts efficiency.

  • From Discovery to Master Data: The process doesn't end with finding a great supplier. Once a promising partner is identified, the purchaser can automatically notify the Master Data Specialist back in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. This kicks off your internal process to formally add the new supplier as a vendor, ready for follow-on documents and transactions.

  • Controlled and Secure Access: Even without a full SAP Business Network subscription, your users can perform these searches. Furthermore, you can configure specific roles within the Business Network to ensure your S/4HANA users have permission only to search and discover, maintaining control over your procurement activities.

The Configuration Roadmap: A High-Level Overview

Now that you see the value, you're probably wondering, "How do we set this up?" While the SAP Help Portal has the detailed, step-by-step instructions, I'd like to give you a high-level roadmap of the configuration journey. It involves connecting three key components: your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system, your Identity Authentication service (IAS), and your SAP Business Network account.

Phase 1: Laying the Foundation (Prerequisites)

Before you begin, you need to ensure the groundwork is in place.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud: The most important prerequisite is ensuring that scope item 7VL (Supplier Integration) is active in your system. You can check this in the 'Manage Your Solution' app or through SAP Central Business Configuration. If it's not active, you'll need to request its activation.

In SAP Business Network: You'll need a buyer organization and an administrator account. If you don't have access, your Designated Support Contact can help you get set up by logging a service request.

Phase 2: Building the Bridge (Authentication & SSO)

This is the technical heart of the integration, ensuring seamless and secure user access.

  1. Configure in Identity Authentication Service (IAS): First, you'll set up an application for the SAP Business Network within your corporate IAS tenant. This is what enables your S/4HANA Cloud users to be recognized by the Business Network.

  2. Configure on SAP Business Network: This step requires collaboration with SAP. You'll need to gather specific metadata from your IAS tenant (like the certificate and assertion URLs) and provide them to the SAP Business Network operations team via a service request. They will use this information to configure your IAS as a trusted identity provider, enabling the SSO functionality.

Phase 3: Preparing the Destination (SAP Business Network User Setup)

With the trust relationship established, you need to prepare the Business Network to receive your users.

  1. Create a Custom Role: To ensure proper governance, you'll log in to your Business Network buyer account and create a new, restricted role. A good practice is to name it something like "S/4HANA Supplier Search" and grant it only the permission to "Create postings on Ariba Discovery."
  2. Create and Assign a User: You will then create a user (or users) and assign them this newly created, restricted role. This ensures that when your purchasers land in the Business Network, their capabilities are appropriately limited to discovery.

Phase 4: Connecting from Home Base (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Setup)

The final step is to configure the tile in the Fiori launchpad that will take your users to the Business Network.

  1. Create a Communication System: In your S/4HANA Cloud system, you'll use the 'Communication Systems' app to define the SAP Business Network as a known external system.
  2. Create a Communication Arrangement: Using the 'Communication Arrangements' app, you'll create an arrangement for the scenario SAP_COM_0A84 (SAP Business Network â€“ Supplier Search UI Integration). Here, you'll link the Communication System you just created and provide the specific path to the Business Network search UI. This finalizes the connection.

And that's it! By connecting these powerful platforms, you empower your procurement team, streamline supplier discovery, and build a more resilient and diverse supply chain.

As always, for any issues during configuration, you can raise an SAP Support ticket. The SAP Help Portal and SAP Community are your best resources for detailed guides and expert advice.

Happy integrating!

entry.title: Re: U.S SECURE 2.0 Act - Section 603
entry.content:
Hello @Euna,

You can have a single plan that includes both regular and catch-up contributions. While the regular contribution of this plan can be configured for both post-tax (Roth) and pre-tax contributions simultaneously, the catch-up contribution can only consider one type (pre-tax or post-tax). The wage type configured in the "EE Catch-up contrib." field of view V_T7USBEN03 will determine whether the catch-up plan is selected for pre-tax or post-tax. This behavior has not changed with section 603.

What was modified with the solution delivered to address the legal changes from section 603 is that the system now, depending on your configuration, allows the automatic conversion of catch-up contributions from pre-tax to post-tax. This occurs only if the employee reached the maximum FICA limit in the prior year, as per Note 3617266.

entry.title: The Importance of Primary Finance Settings in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
• This blog is based on version CE2508.
  • The screenshots shown come from an internal SAP test system.

This blog is designed for consultants and customers who are just beginning their journey with SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition). Understanding and correctly configuring the Primary Finance Settings is one of the most critical early steps in an implementation project.

 

Why Primary Finance Settings Matter?

At the start of any SAP Cloud ERP implementation, defining the Primary Finance Settings is a fundamental activity. These settings include:

  • Fiscal Year Variant

  • Group Currency

  • Ledgers and Accounting Principles

These initial configurations form the financial backbone of your system. They directly influence all subsequent financial postings, ledgers, and company codes across your organization. Since they are deeply embedded in the system structure, they must be carefully planned and chosen â€” because once saved, they cannot be changed.

 

What are the Primary Finance Settings?
The â€œSpecify Primary Finance Settingsâ€ activity is a one-time configuration in SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC).

Here, you define two crucial values:

  • Fiscal Year Variant (FYV): Determines how your financial year is divided (e.g., calendar or non-calendar year).

  • Group Currency: Ensures consistent and comparable financial reporting across your global entities.

Once these values are saved, they cannot be changed.

The system even displays a clear message:
â€œBe aware that this is a one-time decision which cannot be changed.â€ This highlights just how significant these settings are for your overall ERP landscape.

 

How can I configure the Primary Finance Settings?

Step 1: Selecting Ledgers and Accounting Principles

The number and type of ledgers are defined during the initial scoping phase, and â€” just like the other finance settings â€” cannot be modified later.

During the Define Scope activity, youâ€™ll select the scope items that determine which ledgers are activated:

  • J58 â€“ Activates the Leading Ledger (0L), assigned to the local GAAP at company code level.

  • 1GA â€“ Activates Ledger 2L, corresponding to IFRS accounting principles.

  • 2VA â€“ Activates Ledger 3L, corresponding to US GAAP accounting principles.

Important:
If you choose to work only with one ledger (0L), IFRS and US GAAP principles and their related content will not be available.

For multi-ledger setups, ensure each ledger is assigned to the correct accounting principle. In this blog, I provided detailed guidance: SAP Recommendation: Assignment of Corporate Accounting Principle to Ledger. 

 

Step 2: Defining the Fiscal Year Variant and Group Currency
Within the Specify Primary Finance Settings activity, you select:

  • Fiscal Year Variant (FYV): Defines your companyâ€™s financial reporting structure â€” for instance, whether your fiscal year aligns with the calendar year or follows a custom pattern.

  • Group Currency: A key value that drives consistent financial consolidation and reporting across all entities and ledgers.

 

 

Where Do These Settings Apply?

The Fiscal Year Variant selected during setup is applied to the Leading Ledger and cannot be changed later.

  • Non-leading Ledgers will inherit this setting, but can be adjusted if necessary.

For a full list of supported fiscal year variants, please refer to the SAP Road Map Viewer> SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3-system landscape) > Explore phase >  accelerator file â€œSupported Fiscal Year Variant.xlsxâ€

The Group Currency applies to all ledgers and company codes in the system.

 

What If You Need to Modify These Settings?

If you realize that your initial configuration was incorrect or needs to be changed, the only option is to request a System Reprovisioning.

However, be aware:

This process can delay your project timeline by more than three weeks.

Please find more details:

  • 3401017 - FAQs about S/4HANA Public Cloud System Reprovisioning
  • Getting started with your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Project - Dodging the System Re-Provisioning Bullets 

To conclude:

The Primary Finance Settings define the financial core of your SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition system.  Because these settings are permanent, always validate your selections carefully before saving. Taking the time to get them right up front will save time on rework and delays later.

 

SAP Help Portal Links:

  • Setting Your Group Currency 
  • Fiscal Year and Fiscal Year Variant 
  • Ledger

 

If you find this information helpful, please remember to give a kudo.

Stay tuned for more tips and insights!

entry.title: Re: How to process a sales order without recognizing reve...
entry.content:
Hello @Meghan4201 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Sales in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, Sales in SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2202.2

Billing Document Types, Event-Based Revenue Recognition

In summary, you can capture the supplier purchase and consumption without recognising revenue by not creating a billing document in public cloud (goods movement only). If you require a formal invoice, you can create a billing document that posts to a non-revenue/clearing GL. This requires account determination configuration in the cloud. I recommend you first validate the no-billing approach in a sandbox and confirm tax/finance acceptance. If an invoice is mandatory, you should implement a non-revenue billing type through the supported cloud configuration path.

Below are steps to validate the billing type (that adheres to the clean-core approach).

Search for Manage Sales Orders Ã  Create the sales order per the normal process.

Save the order.

Create of confirm Delivery/Goods Movement as you require. Use Create Outbound Delivery/Post Goods Issue. Ensure the posting is a goods movement that does not automatically trigger a billing.

Do not execute Create Billing Document for that sales order. By skipping, no revenue invoice will be created and no revenue GL postings will be generated.

If you need accounting offset (internal settlement), post a clearing/settlement document manually or through a follow-up process

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Process complete confirmation all at once
entry.content:
Good day @Lily16 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Dump with MESSAGE_TYPE_X SAPLFKB0 >0 361 >0 428 or >0 361 FKKLOCKS 022, Completing Confirmation,

Community similar cases: Internal session terminated with a runtime error MESSAGE_TYPE_X

To summarise, based on the error translation, the problem seems to be a runtime error due to OData request terminating abnormally. The system tries to recalculate completion data across all items, it finds inconsistent dependencies, and raises an exception in the backend OData component, which then triggers that error.

A workaround could be to confirm your main items separately, do not select all items at once. Just as you have done, select and confirm the external service subitems individually, then, select only the main service bundle item and execute Complete Confirmation. This should prevent the OData aggregation error.

If the issue persists, consider raising a support case with SAP.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

GenAI was use to generate translation content

entry.title: Accelerating SAP BTP Integrations with GPT-5: Introducing the SAP Integration AI Assistant
entry.content:
Introduction

AI is transforming how we work. Over the last few years, tools like ChatGPT have evolved from simple chat interfaces to intelligent partners that can understand complex technical problems.

As an SAP Integration professional, I started thinking â€” what if we could bring that same level of intelligence into the world of SAP BTP Integration Suite?

Having worked with SAP CPI, API Management, and Event Mesh, Iâ€™ve often seen teams spending countless hours writing Groovy scripts, debugging mappings, and testing iFlows. These tasks are essential but repetitive â€” and thatâ€™s exactly where AI can help.

This thought led me to create something new: the SAP Integration AI Assistant â€” an intelligent support tool built using GPT-5, designed specifically for SAP Integration developers and consultants.

 

Challenges in SAP Integrations

Working with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) can be both rewarding and demanding. Integration developers often face common challenges such as:

  • Debugging and formatting Groovy scripts

  • Managing complex mappings and error handling

  • Designing reusable iFlows that align with SAP standards

  • Searching through documentation for the right solution

While SAP provides excellent documentation, finding exactly what you need under project pressure can take time. AI can make this process faster and smarter â€” assisting developers with real-time insights.

Meet the SAP Integration AI Assistant

The SAP Integration AI Assistant is built on GPT-5 and trained with integration-specific knowledge. It helps developers solve real project problems efficiently.

Hereâ€™s what it can do:

  • Code Support: Generate, clean, and format Groovy/XSLT/JavaScript scripts with consistent structure.
  • Design Guidance: Suggest iFlow layouts, adapter configurations, and error-handling approaches aligned with best practices.
  • Troubleshooting: Analyze error messages or mapping issues and suggest probable fixes.
  • Learning Tool: Act as a companion for those new to SAP Integration Suite, explaining concepts and configurations clearly.

Itâ€™s like having a virtual SAP Integration mentor â€” available anytime you need it.

Built from Real Project Experience

This idea came from years of working on integration projects across global landscapes â€” building, optimizing, and reviewing iFlows in SAP BTP.

The assistant is designed to share this accumulated experience. It transforms real-world learnings into actionable insights that any developer can use directly in their daily work.

Getting Started

You can begin experimenting with the SAP Integration AI Assistant right away.

Use it to:

  • Generate or optimize Groovy/XSLT code
  • Validate iFlow designs and configurations
  • Troubleshoot mapping or adapter errors
  • Explore integration scenarios with API Management and Event Mesh

 Try it here:  SAP Integration AI Assistant   

 

Sample Examples

 

Conclusion

AI is no longer a future trend â€” itâ€™s an everyday tool for developers.
By combining SAP Integration expertise with AI capabilities, we can build integrations faster, reduce manual effort, and improve quality.

entry.title: Re: Getting error when opening excel file using GUI download
entry.content: Maybe you're not aware of what can be an "Excel file". It can be different formats, text (ASC) or binary (BIN). Both can themselves be divided into several subformats: text can be CSV (colon or semicolon depending on countries)), tab-separated fields (suffix .txt), fixed-width columns. Binary files can be the formats XLS, XLSX, etc. Also, you have to understand that the format and the file extension are two different things, but they must match otherwise Excel displays an alert. XLSX is like a ZIP file containing many XML files.

entry.title: Re: Do adding the setup formula to processing unit have a...
entry.content:
https://me.sap.com/notes/2584494/E

Differences between Production order scheduling and Process order scheduling:

  • Production orders are only scheduled one direction based on the indicated scheduling type. Process orders are always scheduling both backwards and forwards.
  • Production orders are scheduled based on operation sequence. Process orders are scheduled on phase relationship.
  • Production order operations have 3 segments: Setup, Processing, Teardown, so 3 formulas can be configured in work center. Process order phases don't have segments, so only 1 formula in resource.

entry.title: Deletion of Basic data text in Material is not replicating from S4 to ECC
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We have observed that when the basic data text (STXH) exists for a material, the data replicates correctly from S/4 to ECC, and the MATMAS message includes the segment E1MTXHM as expected. However, when we delete the basic data text for the material, the change is not replicated properly to ECC. In this case, the E1MTXHM segment is missing from the MATMAS message, whereas we would expect it to be present with the '003' MSGFN (function code for deletion).

It appears that the standard process deletes the segment entirely, instead of sending an update with MSGFN '003'. Could someone advise on how to ensure that the E1MTXHM segment is included in the MATMAS message to ECC with MSGFN '003' when the basic data text is deleted?
Can someone guide me which badi need to use?
I tried in IDOC_DATA_INSERT but still no luck . 
It would be great if someone can provide a sample code.

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: workflow approval process
entry.content:
Good day @jerrysam 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions, Extensibility and Integration Concepts

Blog: Empowering business users to create new workflows with S/4HANA Cloud, public edition and SAP BTP - Part 1 (see part 2 & 3 in blog)

Blog: Part 1: Integrating an Extension Workflow on SAP BTP into a Flexible Workflow

In summary, the reason for the error (double approval) is, in public cloud, duplicate approvals occur because both the BTP and S4H flexible workflow are active. The easiest way to prevent this is for you to:  

  • Control the workflow start conditions inside your public cloud tenant.
  • Add a custom flag in the integration payload to identify BTP- originated documents or,
  • Fully centralise approval in BTP and disable the PO workflow in S/4HANA.

I recommend you consider the first two because they follow the public cloud clean core approach

Below is detailed flow on how to control the workflow start conditions inside you public cloud tenant:

Search for Manage Workflow for Purchase Orders

Open your active workflow --> navigate to the start conditions tab. 

Add a new condition that checks the origin or custom field of the Purchase Order. An example could be â€œCustom Field â€œCreated via BTP Workflowâ€ =True or PR Source System = BTP. Make sure you donâ€™t trigger the PO approval workflow list.

This will ensure your Purchase Orders created from approved PRs in BTP will bypass the S/4HANA approval workflow. 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Como a Reforma TributÃ¡ria no Brasil Impacta os usuÃ¡rios SAP
entry.content:
A reforma tributÃ¡ria no Brasil Ã© um tema de grande relevÃ¢ncia para empresas que precisam se adaptar a estas mudanÃ§as legais. Para os usuÃ¡rios SAP, Ã© importante entender como a reforma afeta os processos logÃ­sticos e financeiros, estar ciente dos prazos de implantaÃ§Ã£o e saber quais sÃ£o as soluÃ§Ãµes providas pela SAP para garantir uma transiÃ§Ã£o tranquila.

Cronograma de ImplementaÃ§Ã£o da Reforma

  • 2026: A reforma tributÃ¡ria comeÃ§a a ser testada, com taxas iniciais mais baixas de 0,9% para a ContribuiÃ§Ã£o sobre Bens e ServiÃ§os (CBS) e 0,1% para o Imposto sobre Bens e ServiÃ§os (IBS).
  • 2027: A CBS passa a valer, substituindo PIS e Cofins. A alÃ­quota de IPI serÃ¡ zerada, exceto para produtos industrializados na ZFM.
  • 2028: Ãšltimo ano de ICMS e ISS sem alteraÃ§Ã£o.
  • 2029: EliminaÃ§Ã£o gradual do ICMS e ISS, com reduÃ§Ã£o anual de 10% em suas taxas, como parte da substituiÃ§Ã£o pelo IBS.
  • 2033: AdoÃ§Ã£o integral do novo regime tributÃ¡rio, com a extinÃ§Ã£o de ICMS e ISS.

Entregas da SAP
A SAP estÃ¡ comprometida em apoiar seus clientes durante a transiÃ§Ã£o para o novo modelo tributÃ¡rio. As soluÃ§Ãµes SAP estÃ£o sendo atualizadas para atender aos novos requisitos legais, garantindo que as empresas possam se adequar Ã s mudanÃ§as.

SNOTE: Note Analyzer tool
Recomendamos fortemente o uso da ferramenta Note Analyzer para organizar a implementaÃ§Ã£o das SAP Notes desta soluÃ§Ã£o. Consulte a SAP Note 3200109 para obter instruÃ§Ãµes sobre essa ferramenta e utilize o arquivo XML anexo Ã  SAP Note 3561376 para relacionar as entregas da SAP para a Reforma TributÃ¡ria do Brasil. A versÃ£o mais recente do Note Analyzer introduz um recurso que exibe a ordem de implementaÃ§Ã£o na coluna "comentÃ¡rios" apÃ³s a importaÃ§Ã£o do XML. Siga esta ordem, mesmo que algumas SAP Notes nÃ£o sejam relevantes para o seu negÃ³cio. Observe que a ferramenta fornece a ordem correta, mas nÃ£o uma lista completa dos prÃ©-requisitos das SAP Notes. Assim, anÃ¡lises adicionais podem ser necessÃ¡rias para lidar com possÃ­veis dependÃªncias.

ObservaÃ§Ãµes importantes durante a implementaÃ§Ã£o das SAP notes
Para cada nota SAP que serÃ¡ implementada, reserve um momento para ler o seu conteÃºdo em texto. Desta forma, serÃ¡ possÃ­vel se informar sobre notas prÃ©-requisito conhecidas, passos manuais a serem executados antes ou depois da implementaÃ§Ã£o automÃ¡tica das instruÃ§Ãµes de correÃ§Ã£o, assim como ficar ciente de outras instruÃ§Ãµes. A leitura do conteÃºdo de cada nota a ser implementada pode evitar problemas de implementaÃ§Ã£o e a necessidade de retrabalho.
AlÃ©m disso, Ã© muito importante nÃ£o prosseguir para a implementaÃ§Ã£o de SAP notes subsequentes deixando notas anteriores incorretamente implementadas no sistema (status incompletely implemented), pois isso leva a um sistema corrompido e sem os contextos e objetos necessÃ¡rios para futuras implementaÃ§Ãµes. Portanto, ao implementar uma lista de SAP Notes, assegure-se de que cada nota estÃ¡ sendo implementada corretamente e completamente.

Recursos de Apoio
A SAP disponibiliza vÃ¡rios recursos de apoio, entre eles:

  • SAP Work Zone - Brazil - Tax Reform Localization: Permite que clientes e parceiros da SAP compartilhem informaÃ§Ãµes e colaborem em assuntos relacionados Ã  Reforma TributÃ¡ria. Este espaÃ§o tem atualizaÃ§Ã£o diÃ¡ria.
  • SAP Note 3561376 - Tax Reform Leading SAP Note para leitura: Descreve a estratÃ©gia de entrega e suporte para a soluÃ§Ã£o de Reforma TributÃ¡ria do Brasil. Esta nota, de atualizaÃ§Ã£o frequente, lista as entregas da soluÃ§Ã£o conforme sÃ£o liberadas para clientes. Assim, anexado a ela estÃ¡ o arquivo XML sempre atualizado para o uso no Note Analyzer, auxiliando a implementaÃ§Ã£o das SAP Notes na ordem adequada.
  • SAP Note 3637842 - Brazil Tax Reform - Testing Limitations with SEFAZ para leitura: Esta SAP Note informativa destaca os processos ainda nÃ£o suportados pela SAP relacionados Ã  Reforma TributÃ¡ria no Brasil, especialmente sobre cenÃ¡rios a serem testados com a SEFAZ. Esta nota serÃ¡ atualizada regularmente.
  • KBA 3642384 - Brazil Tax Reform Troubleshooting Guide: AlÃ©m de explicar sobre a entrega da SAP e trazer os links diretos da plataforma Regulatory Change Manager para os assuntos da Reforma TributÃ¡ria, este KBA de Troubleshooting auxilia a resolver os possÃ­veis problemas jÃ¡ identificados durante a implementaÃ§Ã£o das SAP notes. Ao oferecer soluÃ§Ãµes para problemas comuns, este KBA Ã© continuamente atualizado para incluir novas informaÃ§Ãµes.

Prazo de ImplementaÃ§Ã£o para clientes
Os clientes SAP precisam ter as soluÃ§Ãµes SAP referentes Ã  reforma tributÃ¡ria totalmente implementadas e testadas atÃ© dezembro de 2025, para garantir conformidade com as novas obrigaÃ§Ãµes a partir de janeiro de 2026.

ValidaÃ§Ã£o por parte do governo
Atualmente, Ã© possÃ­vel testar a aprovaÃ§Ã£o de documentos com os campos dos novos tributos em ambiente de homologaÃ§Ã£o da SEFAZ e, de forma facultativa, enviÃ¡-los tambÃ©m em produÃ§Ã£o.
O ambiente produtivo da SEFAZ comeÃ§arÃ¡ a validar os novos campos de XML da NF-e relacionados aos impostos da reforma tributÃ¡ria a partir de janeiro de 2026. AtÃ© essa data, o preenchimento desses novos campos Ã© facultativo e, mesmo que preenchidos, nÃ£o devem causar rejeiÃ§Ã£o na aprovaÃ§Ã£o da NF-e.
A partir de janeiro de 2026, o preenchimento dos campos dos novos impostos serÃ¡ obrigatÃ³rio, com valor jurÃ­dico, para documentos fiscais eletrÃ´nicos em ambiente de produÃ§Ã£o. A nÃ£o conformidade poderÃ¡ levar Ã  rejeiÃ§Ã£o das notas fiscais.

ConclusÃ£o
A reforma tributÃ¡ria no Brasil traz uma mudanÃ§a legal significativa, portanto, esteja atento ao prazo de adequaÃ§Ã£o.
As notas informativas da SAP listadas acima e o KBA de troubleshooting seguirÃ£o em constante atualizaÃ§Ã£o para que vocÃª tenha acesso a informaÃ§Ãµes relevantes enquanto atualiza o seu sistema.

entry.title: Unlocking the Power of Model Context Protocol (MCP) for SAP Business Applications
entry.content:
What is Model Context Protocol?

In todayâ€™s rapidly evolving enterprise landscape, SAP business applications are at the heart of mission-critical operationsâ€”from Order to Cash and Procure to Pay, to Financial Reporting and beyond. Yet, many organizations still face persistent challenges: siloed data, fragmented workflows, and manual processes that slow innovation and limit agility.

Model Context Protocol (MCP) represents a breakthrough in how Generative AIâ€”including Large Language Models (LLMs)â€”can drive real business outcomes within SAP environments. MCP transforms AI from a passive responder into an active agent, capable of planning, orchestrating, and executing complex business tasks across diverse SAP and non-SAP systems

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) enables any functionality to be exposed as AI-accessible tools, allowing models to not only understand a request but also act to fulfil it.

Born from Anthropicâ€™s work on the Claude Code IDE, MCP was designed to seamlessly integrate a wide range of capabilities â€” from multi-language programming support to CI/CD frameworks and dependency management â€” directly into the AIâ€™s operational toolkit. Instead of retraining models for every new capability, MCP gives them instant access to the tools they need.

Unlike Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), which focuses on providing extra context to the model, MCP goes further â€” it provides actionable functionality. When combined, RAG and MCP form a powerful framework: RAG informs the AI with relevant knowledge, while MCP equips it with the means to execute tasks.

This synergy enables AI to plan, select the right tools, and carry out complex operations â€” paving the way for true agentic applications in enterprise environments. For SAP business applications, MCP is not just an enhancement â€” itâ€™s the future of how AI will work with systems to drive automation, decision-making, and innovation.

How MCP works?

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) operates on clientâ€“server architecture model that transforms Large Language Models (LLMs) from passive responders into active agents capable of executing complex business tasks. On the server side, MCP hosts a library of well-defined tools â€” each with clear input/output specifications â€” that can securely access data, run processes, and return results. These servers can run locally for tasks that donâ€™t require cloud services, or be securely hosted to connect with databases, SAP systems, and other enterprise platforms. On the client side, the MCP client acts as the bridge between the LLM and the server: it injects the right context from the user request, discovers available tools via frameworks like LangGraph, and enables the LLM to plan, select, and invoke the appropriate tool. The results are fed back to the LLM, which then produces a polished, context-aware response for the user. By connecting to multiple MCP servers, applications can tap into diverse capabilities across domains â€” enabling true agentic intelligence where AI autonomously plans, executes, and delivers business outcomes.

Key capabilities of MCP:

 

How is it Applicable to SAP Business Applications

The Model Context Protocol (MCP) has strong applicability to SAP business applications when viewed from both a business and technical perspective.

From a business perspective, SAP applications support complex, end-to-end scenarios across multiple lines of business such as Order to Cash, Procure to Pay, Hire to Retire, Materials Planning, and Financial Reporting and many more. Each of these high-level process drills down further into granular Level 2 and Level 3 processes, where specific operational steps occur. On a client landscape, the data for these processes might exist on different SAP or non-SAP systems. This poses a problem to the end-to-end process flows as this data is siloed and difficult to access.

The MCP tools can be designed to align directly with these sub-processes existing on multiple systems, enabling agentic AI clients to interpret a userâ€™s request, extract relevant context using the tools, plan the necessary sequence of actions, and then invoke the right tools to perform operations on SAP systems. This means that tasks which traditionally require manual navigation through multiple SAP transactions can now be automated, orchestrated, and executed intelligently by AI.

 

From a technical perspective, SAP ecosystem offers cloud-native capabilities via SAP BTP and Kyma, which can host and run MCP servers with well-defined tools. An MCP client could, for example, can be implemented as a lightweight Flask application with multiple API routes, each tailored for specific user requests. When a request comes in, the client extracts the context, passes it to the LLM, and the LLM determines the required actions before calling the appropriate MCP server tools. This client application can be deployed on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and integrated with a CAP application, complete with a user interface â€” such as BPA forms or interactive UI apps â€” to give end users a seamless working environment or integrated with Joule Studio

In essence, MCP server and client mechanisms can function as microservices that integrate effortlessly with SAP applications on SAP BTP, enabling:

  • Direct alignment of MCP tools with SAP Level 2 and Level 3 processes.
  • Secure execution of business logic via SAP ODATA services and BTP-hosted MCP servers bringing in data from other Applications into SAP.
  • Context-aware orchestration of actions by LLMs, reducing manual intervention.

By combining SAPâ€™s robust business processes with MCPâ€™s agentic capabilities, enterprises can move toward a future where SAP applications are not only transactional but also intelligent, autonomous, and proactive in delivering business outcomes.

Example implementation

Consider a comprehensive Vendor Onboarding scenario â€” one that not only creates vendors in the SAP system but also validates their details via multiple external APIs, retrieves information from various sources, identifies missing data, generates a targeted questionnaire, and sends it to the vendor contact for completion.

Traditionally, this process takes several days and involves multiple teams working across different systems to collect, verify, and enter vendor details into SAP. Using Large Language Models (LLMs) combined with MCP servers and tools, this workflow can be transformed into Agentic Automation â€” where AI autonomously plans and executes the onboarding steps based on the specific vendorâ€™s context. The automation adapts dynamically to each case, using available information and determining what needs to be collected, drastically reducing onboarding time while leveraging existing tools in the customerâ€™s landscape.

In the recent SAPâ€“AWS Hack2Build event, IBM implemented an agentic Sustainability skills using MCP serverâ€“client architecture using SAP BTP and AWS joint reference architecture as follows:

  1. API Availability: The necessary Sustainability Tracing APIs were already built and exposed via AWS API Gateway.
  2. MCP Server Setup: An MCP server was created to expose these AWS APIs, making them directly callable by the LLM. Without MCP, the APIs could only be used by other applications or services â€” not directly by AI agents.
  3. Hosting on SAP BTP: The MCP server was deployed and run on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, ensuring secure and scalable access.
  4. MCP Client Application: A lightweight HTTP-routes-based MCP client was built to handle natural language queries from end users.
    • The client extracts context and parameters from the user request using the LLM.
    • It calls the LLM with the relevant tools and parameters so the AI can decide when to use a tool â€” and when not to, in case of a generic question.
    • This client was also hosted on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry and connected to the MCP server to list and use tools dynamically based on the request.
  5. CAP Application Integration: A CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application was used as the frontend/UI layer, sending the userâ€™s request to the MCP client and displaying results back to the user.

By simply using the MCP server and client framework hosted on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, we built an end-to-end agentic application. This approach not only integrates external APIs directly into the SAP landscape but also provides a scalable pattern to make existing SAP applications agentic â€” enabling them to autonomously plan, execute, and adapt workflows.

 

 

Business Value and Benefits

Effective Agentic Automation is becoming one of the most impactful approaches to enterprise process automation, offering strategic and operational advantages across SAP landscapes. Traditionally, automation initiatives have focused on the â€œhappy pathâ€ â€” the ideal scenario where processes execute exactly as planned. However, large organizations experience happy paths only about 40% of the time. The remaining majority are exceptions caused by regional variations, departmental workflows, process differences, compliance requirements, or unforeseen data gaps.

This is exactly where the Model Context Protocol (MCP) integrated with SAP business applications delivers transformative value. Rather than relying on rigid, rule-based flows, MCP enables agentic systems that adapt to context in real time. LLM-powered MCP clients can understand nuanced user requests, identify what information is available, determine what is missing, plan next steps dynamically, and call the right tools to complete the process â€” whether the scenario follows the happy path or not.

Applied to SAP, this means:

  • End-to-end process automation for complex scenarios like Vendor Onboarding, Order to Cash, or Procure to Pay, without manual form-filling or multiple transaction hops, and integrating external tools within SAP workflows.
  • Adaptive workflows that can continue operating despite ambiguity, incomplete data, or process deviations.
  • Human oversight with reduced workload, where operators monitor progress and guide agents in exceptional cases, rather than executing every step themselves.
  • Integration of external APIs and internal services, bringing together SAP ODATA services, SAP BTP microservices, and third-party tools under a single agentic control layer.

By hosting MCP servers and clients on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, organizations can make existing SAP applications truly agentic â€” systems that donâ€™t just respond to requests but can plan, decide, and act in pursuit of business goals. The result is a significant reduction in process cycle times, improved operational efficiency, and greater flexibility in handling real-world complexity.

In short, MCP brings the intelligence and adaptability needed to turn SAP into a proactive business partner â€” one that can automate not just the ideal scenarios, but also the messy, exception-driven realities that dominate enterprise operations.

Things to look out for

While the Model Context Protocol (MCP) offers powerful capabilities to make SAP applications agentic, there are several critical considerations that must be addressed to ensure secure, reliable, and scalable deployments:

  1. Security of Applications â€“ MCP servers and clients can be hosted across different environments, and tools may need to access data from multiple sources. This distributed nature requires end-to-end security planning, including authentication, authorization, encryption, and secure API access. Role propagation across systems is essential so that permissions are consistently enforced throughout the workflow.
  2. Context Engineering â€“ The quality and precision of context passed to the LLM directly determines which tools are invoked and in what sequence. Poorly defined context can lead to incorrect tool calls or inefficient workflows. Each use case may require careful context design and parameter mapping to ensure the LLM receives exactly the right inputs for optimal execution. This often requires iterative refinement during testing and rollout.
  3. Performance & Scalability â€“ MCP-enabled workflows can involve multiple tool calls, external API requests, and data processing steps. In high-volume SAP environments, this can introduce latency if not optimized. Itâ€™s important to design for efficient tool execution, minimize unnecessary calls, cache frequently accessed data where appropriate, and ensure the MCP server infrastructure is scalable to handle concurrent requests without impacting business SLAs. Monitoring and load testing should be part of the deployment strategy.

Conclusion

The MCP Server and Client framework has the potential to transform SAP applications into truly agentic systems. By using tools exposed through MCP servers â€” and seamlessly integrating them with SAP BTP we can have a variety of tools that bring extensive functionality to Generative AI models â€” enterprises can unlock a new level of intelligent automation. With the ability to reason, plan, and decide the next steps in a process, AI agents can autonomously execute workflows while still operating under human oversight. This ensures that productivity and efficiency gains are not only substantial but also practical and measurable, delivering real business impact.

Why invest in MCP now?

As AI becomes central to enterprise strategy, MCP unlocks the potential for SAP applications to become truly intelligent, autonomous, and proactive partners in business success. By bridging the gap between AI reasoning and enterprise action, MCP empowers leaders to realize tangible ROI, accelerate innovation, and future-proof their SAP investments.

To learn more, do meet us at SAP TechEd, AWS Re:Invent or connect with us via LinkedIn.

entry.title: Re: Master Logistics Series :Outbound Logistics with SAP Logistics Management-Direct LTL Variant
entry.content:
Hi @Bimal_S ,

Thanks for the comment .

This is not an IM Storage location , it is a storage location that is tied to a warehouse .In S/4 ,LGM warehouse is considered as third party decentralized warehouse .

Follow these steps :

  1. Define a storage location under Enterprise Structure >Definition  Materials Management -> Maintain Storage Location.

  2. Define a warehouse number under Enterprise Structure > Definition  Logistics Execution > Define Warehouse Number.

  3. Assign the warehouse number to the storage location under Enterprise Structure  >Assignment  Logistics Execution > Assign Warehouse Number to Plant and Storage Location.

  4. Under Logistics Execution  Integration of External Warehouse Systems  >Activate Decentralized Warehouse System, activate the warehouse as a third-party warehouse by the following settings:

    • Selecting External WMS

    • Choosing SOAP Web Services for Communication External WM

    • Choosing Distribution Immediately at Document Creation for Dist. Mode for the Delivery

entry.title: Content Agent now supports modifiable Transport Request
entry.content:
Overview

With the latest release of SAP Content Agent, you can export the development changes from SAP BTP services such as SAP Integration Suite,  Role Collections etc, to an existing modifiable transport request created in SAP Cloud Transport Management Service. You can also choose to create a new Transport Request and select the option to keep it "modifiable". 

This feature would help the users to collect all related changes and iterative changes into single transport request which makes it more manageable to review and process the requests.

Try it out!

  1. Launch the Content Agent UI from your development account by subscribing to the "free" plan and assign the required "Content Agent Export Operator" or "Content Agent Admin" role collection to your user.
    See Subscribe the UI plan and Assign User Roles and Permissions.
  2.  Launch the UI, and navigate to Content Types page. Check the status of the content type that you wish to export and if it is inactive, use the automation feature.
    See the details as described here: Automated Integration in SAP Content Agent to enable BTP services for transport 

  3. Navigate to Export page and use the wizard steps to select and export content.
    There are two options provided to you. 
    a)  You can choose Create a New Transport Request option if you want to create a new request in Cloud Transport Management. You can Select the checkbox Keep this Transport Request modifiable if you want to append content later to this transport request.  

    â€ƒb) Choose Existing Transport Request presents the input box to type in the Transport Request Id. The UI also provides the option to view the list of existing modifiable Transport Request ID along with description and source node. This would append the content bundled as MTAR into the existing Transport Request in Cloud Transport Management. 


  4. Proceed to the next step in the wizard which triggers an asynchronous process. Once completed, you can check the Activities Performed page for more details.

  5. Navigate to the Cloud Transport Management UI to view the complete details of transport Request status. 

     

Summary

Use the feature from Content Agent UI enabling the creation and changes to modifiable transport request towards your SAP Cloud Changes. 
For more details on managing modifiable transport requests, refer to https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/modifiable-transport-requests-now-also-for-your-sap-cloud-changes/ba-p/14194823 .

entry.title: Re: Requirement is to restrict Unblock payment tab in man...
entry.content:
Good day @sandeep_shankarampet 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Manage Automatic Payments, Business Role - Restriction Entity, Financing Order Processing, SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments, Manage Payment Blocks

In public cloud edition, you can control both â€œBlock for Paymentâ€ and Unblock for Paymentâ€ by the same authorisation object (Authorization Group for Journal Entry Document Type). However, these two actions cannot be separated directly through these restrictions alone, reason is, SAP delivers them as part of the same Business Catalog permissions under Accounts Payable or Accounts Receivable roles. That means:

  • When you remove the Authorization Group restriction, you are blocking access to both processes.
  • When you reassign it, the system restores access to both actions.

I recommend taking a clean-core adherent approach to achieve your business requirement by allowing Block for Payment while restricting Unblock for Payment.

 

First, you need to identify the existing business role. Go to Maintain Business Roles app.

Locate the role that currently allow both actions (as an example, the screenshot below references BR_AP_ACCOUNTANT)

Copy the role that allows both actions

Use a Copy Role and name it as you deem fit and save (For reference purpose I have used ZBR_AP_BLOCK_ONLY in the screenshot)

In the new role, remove FIN_BC_AP_UNBLOCK_PC and keep only FIN_BC_AP_BLOCK_PC. These catalogs correspond to the Block for Payment and Unblock for Payment and save.

Users assigned to the new role can open â€œBlock for Paymentâ€ but cannot access the â€œUnblock for Paymentâ€ app. Thereafter, assign the new role to the specific users who should have Block only authorisation and save.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Regards,

Duong

entry.title: S/4 HANA TM: Basic vs Advance- Deciding Factors & Your Strategy
entry.content:
<Note : Article has referred SAP Note 3065464>

Basic TM: More Power Under the Hood Than You Think

Don't underestimate the Basic Transportation Management (TM) license. Many assume it only handles simple, straight-line shipments, leading them to overlook its true value. In fact, Basic TM offers a robust foundation for complex logistics right out of the box.

You might be surprised by what's included without needing the Advanced license:

  • Complex Route Planning is fully supported. Basic TM handles both multi-pick and multi-drop scenarios for both incoming (inbound) and outgoing (outbound) deliveries.
  • The Critical Restriction: The only key limitation is that you cannot combine Freight Units from inbound and outbound deliveries onto the same Freight Order.
  • Core Execution and Settlement: It supports FSD creation , and generating PO/Service entry sheets.
  • GIS Integration: Direct external GIS hooks for geo-coordinates, distances, and durationsâ€”Basic only, no Advanced needed.
  • Unified Package Building (UPB): Auto-building via Packaging Specifications (PS) or Packing Instructions (PI)â€”basic supports.

A Single Process Step Can Trigger an Advanced License

Nuance is king. The line is indeed "pretty-thin," often hinging on one config or data choice. ( Refre SAP Note 3065464 )

  • Freight Unit Creation: Basic  supports deliveries only. Advanced required for direct from sales/purchase/stock transfer orders (early planning).
  • Freight Rate Tables: Basic limits to 3 scales/dimensions; 4+ scales need Advanced for granularity. Again it does not fullfill many customers wish list but a smart consultant can suggest alternative by following same restriction.
  • Charge Calculation: Be careful many calculation bases can not be used like: Holiday charges etc.
  • Schedules: Basic allows Schedules master data, but "cut-off dates" (e.g., for time windows) are Advanced-only.
  • Resource Management: Basic permits simple "Active Vehicle" in Freight Orders; full Resource objects (vehicles, trailers, drivers) are Advanced. This is really disappointing as my per my experience, it gives lot of pain while suggesting alternatives to client  to manage that .
  • Freight Forwarding: All core capabilities designed for LSPs are Advanced-only. This includes managing Forwarding Orders, Agreements, Settlements, and using Strategic Freight Procurement.
  • Modern Carrier Collaboration: The dedicated suite of Fiori apps for working directly with carriersâ€”covering tendering, order confirmation, execution, and settlementâ€”all require the Advanced TM license

Key Points: The Technical Traps

  • TM-EWM Integration (Advanced Shipping & Receiving - ASR):

Basic TM is allowed only if TM and EWM are embedded within the same S/4HANA system.If you deploy TM or EWM on a separate, decentralized server, the exact same integration instantly demands an Advanced TM license.

  • Side-by-Side Deployments:

The rule is strict: Any standard side-by-side deployment of S/4HANA TM with any other ERP system (ECC, another S/4HANA instance, or a third-party ERP) requires the Advanced TM license.

The exact same business processâ€”integrating TM with an EWM warehouseâ€”can be covered by your Basic license or require a costly Advanced license, based entirely on whether the systems are on the same server or different ones.

JUST THINK: A technical design decision, made without considering licensing knowledge, can lead to multi-million dollar software costs, even when the business process itself is simple.

 

Conclusion: Plan Before You Suggest your client

Choosing between Basic and Advanced Transportation Management is not a simple menu selection; it is a strategic decision that demands a meticulous review of your

  • end-to-end business processes,
  • charge calculation methodologies, 
  • long-term IT landscape strategy.

The line between the two is filled with subtleties that can be easily missed, and the wrong assumption can lead to unplanned costs or functional gaps down the road.

Before you make a final decision, you must map your non-negotiable business requirements against the detailed feature list, go through the notes.

Please share your experience â€“ what strategies you applied during your implementation while being on Basic License.

entry.title: On-Premise Business AI Infrastructure for Small and Medium Enterprises Using NVIDIA DGX Spark
entry.content:
Disclaimer: this article is written without Generative AI, even for the proof reading ğŸ˜Š Enjoy the article written by human that is not common nowadays

Why Business AI?

That is what we always must start with. The business case should go first, for sure, and then we should evaluate possible deployment options, costs and security.

Statistics says that 95% of Generative AI implementations failed and that really scares the market in SAP enterprise software domain as well.

But letâ€™s be honest, we are trying to sell Business AI anywhere as technology, forgetting about the customers, their uniqueness and their current pain points.

At Skybuffer starting from February 2025 (during the last 9 months) we have talked to more than 250 customers of different sizes presenting them Business AI technologies and discussing their use cases, or better to say helping them to find how Business AI can help their employees and partners to automate companyâ€™s workflows.

There are three main groups of use cases, as we see it now:

  • Direct interaction with SAP backend system via corporate messengers that brings simplicity and mobility at the same time. In many cases Creating or Updating data in SAP from mobile phones or via Teams brings real value.
  • Converting any unstructured data to knowledge, like SharePoint sources, attachments in SAP, support tickets. Mixing those things together, in different document original languages create real value for employees providing them access to the data that is hidden in most of the organizations.
  • Capacity heavy activities delivered by AI agents, especially helpful with emails data analysis, where the main data is always in attachments. Sometimes it requires to utilize OCR extracting data from scanned PDFs in those scenarios. Some excellent examples are processing vendors emails and posting invoice or service entry sheets into SAP or receiving emails from customers converting their external purchasing data to sales orders.

That is why SAP customers with any SAP backend system, either SAP ECC or S/4HANA, can implement Business AI today. I am not saying that it covers the entire Business AI implementation benefits, however, that is what we are focusing on now and helping SAP customers to allocate the benefits of using the technology.

Costs

In our opinion, Business AI is close to being the tool that must be deployed inside IT infrastructure, but a technology that is to being considered only if it returns the investment. Think about the indirect impact of missing Business AI in your business landscape. For example, consider the costs of hiring new staff because your employees are moving to other companies that utilize modern technologies. Why should they move? Obvious, because of the same reason we are all talking about Generative AI â€“ to stay competitive on the market.

However, costs of AI must be assessed carefully, because in most of the architecture approaches Business AI is a consumption-based solution. Risky, isnâ€™t it? Of course! Consumption is hard to estimate, and it is also hard to avoid picks, so budgets of Business AI productive usage might be unacceptably high compared to the potential savings the technology brings. That is why we built Skybuffer AI as a solution with the double deployment options:

  • On premise, there is a clear and 100% predictable TCO.
  • On SAP BTP, this is a great option for CPEA contracts, for example, because in this case Business AI consumes the credits that are already paid, and we avoid extra costs for the infrastructure.

Why is DGX Spark in the article name?

Well, DGX Spark here is not because it is a buzz word now, for sure. That is because DGX Spark provides an excellent opportunity for small and medium enterprises to bring 15x15x12 cm GPU-unit to support their Business AI operations for a very compatible price. Actually, it allows us to keep both compute-unit and GPU-unit in the network avoiding data leakage and consumption-based costs. Excellent? Of course!

Here is how we use it deploying Skybuffer AI on premise:

Figure 01. Skybuffer AI deployment with GPU-unit served by DGX Spark

Criticism?

Yes, even writing this article I am already hearing the criticism ğŸ˜Š Guessing the comments like, â€œthat is not for productive environmentâ€, â€œDGX Spark tokens generation too low to serve even Small businessesâ€ and many other sharp negatives. But letâ€™s move back to the beginning of the article and understand the reason why Iâ€™ve spent so much time talking about use cases first. Yes, now it is obvious that many mentioned use cases can be addressed by DGX Spark working as GPU-unit. Example? Easy!

Example #1: Vendor emails processing with data posting into SAP backend and saving originals (files) into the DMS (like SharePoint, Join, Google or whatever DMS is in use).

In the architecture mentioned above, Skybuffer AI allows almost out of the box creation of an AI Agent that will check, for example, Account Payable mailbox, read emails, analyze attachments, move them to DMS and create financial postings in SAP backend saving links to the attachments in DMS (either external or internal SAP DMS) on the SAP financial document level. In scenario, if we schedule the agent carefully, it can work in the almost synchronous 24/7 mode.

In case we schedule the Vendor Emails processing AI Agent with the limit to process just one vendor email in the minute, we will avoid pick system loads, and in this case, we can keep AI agent active 24/7. In such deployment it will be able to process 1 440 emails and create postings in SAP a day, that gives us 43 200 a month and amazing number of 518 400 documents a year!! All powered by one DGX Spark GPU-unit keeping the data on premise and avoiding cloud consumption.

That is what we call a proper deployment of Business AI. And Small and Medium businesses do not usually have such big number of documents from vendors, even the Cirque du Soleil does not have according to the latest SAP news post ğŸ˜Š What we usually do, we add extra Business AI scenarios to be processed by the same Skybuffer AI deployment.

Example #2: Automation of SAP user management services

Small and Medium businesses do use password-based login to SAP backend, so users keep locking themselves or forgetting their passwords. Do we need a powerful GPU-unit with the full size LLM to automate this? No, for sure. We can add those business scenarios to the AI Agent that is processing Vendor Emails ğŸ˜Š

Example #3: Bank data reconciliation

The same setup can be used to assist financial department to match bank transactions to the billing documents in SAP and post accruals for the cases that could not be reconciled, for example, those that miss billing data in SAP that is not created just because someone has forgotten to enter it or integration interfaces have data processing issues. DGX Spark GPU-unit provides particularly good enough capacity here as well.

Those are just a few examples that wind away the skepticism about the utilization of DGX Spark in productive environment.

Is it safe to invest in the on-premise Business AI setup?

If you need full control over costs and data security, the answer is yes. And we think that the answer is yes in general, because Skybuffer AI dual deployment capabilities gives companies the guarantee that on premise Business AI investment can follow their potential future cloud strategy. I am writing and hearing again â€œwhat is this crazy man talking about! On premise investment can follow cloud strategies?? That is a paradox!â€. And again, the answer is No, of course there is no paradox! If we look at the deployment of Skybuffer AI with integration with SAP Joule:

That is what we call real flexibility!

Sounds like a Gap Closing Solution?

Yes, that is the conclusion we have. There no hard choice anymore to run Business AI on premise or on SAP BTP, no prerequisites to start using Business AI, because the deployment in this article works with SAP ECC (down to 7.01 and even below), SAP S/4HANA on premise or SAP S/4HANA in private cloud. The only question must be asked, when we are talking about Business AI, is about the scenario the company should start with? Youâ€™ve seen in our examples that Business AI deployments might bring benefits working in the scenarios that are independent from the historical data you have in your SAP backend and the historical data quality (sometimes it is called data silos), or scenarios that are independent from the version of your system and the point in time of your current digital journey. No need to wait for the upgrades, migrations, or other activities that sound like an act of catching a tail ğŸ˜Š. entry.title: Re: Capacity Scheduling Tables in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Publi...
entry.content:
Hello @nicolasduches 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Capacity Scheduling Table, App Extensibility: Capacity Scheduling Table

To summarise, in public cloud edition, the capacity scheduling table dynamically determines the dispatching date range based on your factory calendar, work center operating times, and current system time zone. The reason you cannot select â€œtodayâ€ in the date range picker is due to how the system enforces capacity dispatching rules, specifically, the Start of Scheduling Intervalâ€ logic that prevents retroactive or mid-shift dispatch.

You can enable same-day dispatch by:

  1. Extending your work center capacity validity to cover the full day.
  2. Confirm your factory calendar marks today as a working day.
  3. Alternatively, you can use the Dispatch from Current Time function.

If you frequently need to dispatch same day operation, I recommend adjusting work center capacity start time. Below is a clean core approach:

Open Manage Work Center app --> Search for your work center

In the search bar, enter the work center ID (e.g., PACK01) --> Go. Select your desired work center from the results list.

Open the capacities tab, here you will find the configuration that controls the valid operating intervals and working time parameters.

Review or adjust the capacity interval. Look for your capacity category --> click the entry to view detailed data. Make sure start time is not later than current system time. Factory Calendar does not mark today as non-working day. Note if the start time = 07:00 and your system time = 16:00, the app considers the shift already in progress and blocks same day dispatch.

If your business wants to allow scheduling any time during the day (for example, 24-hour operation), then your start time = 00:00:00, End Time: 23: 59:00. Keep Length of breaks as 01:00:00 or adjust as needed. Save your changes. This ensures your capacity covers the entire day, so the system will now treat today as open and selectable in the scheduling date range.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Is the billing document type for return orders relate...
entry.content:
Good day @suyoung_choi3 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Credit/Debit Memo - Create for Self-Billing, Customer Returns, Claims, Returns, and Refund Management,

To summarise, the fundamental approach SAP introduced for the public cloud is to keep the core clean. Which also explains why in public cloud SAP uses a single billing type (G2) for all credit transactions to customers. The system distinguishes between goods-related return and value-only credits through the preceding document, item category, and reference flow, not through different billing types. The goal for this approach is to support a clean, standardized, and finance-aligned billing architecture, which is consistent with the clean core strategy.

A glimpse at the E2E process also clarifies this. For the Return Order (with goods movement) it is, Return Order Ã  Return Delivery Ã  Goods Movement Ã  Billing Document (G2) Ã  Accounting: Credit Customer + Reverse COGS

Whilst Credit Memo (without goods movement) is, Credit Memo Request Ã  Billing Document (G2) Ã  Accounting: Credit Customer + Adjust Revenue

Both result in a credit to the customer, but the document flow and accounting impact differ.

Technically, it means:

  • Both documents post to accounts receivable (credit customer) and reverse revenue/COGS depending on the process.
  • SAP standardises the accounting interface by keeping one credit billing type (G2) to simplify integration across Finance, Revenue Accounting, and Returns Management.
  • You cannot create new billing types in public cloud, instead, using the same billing type with different sales document types and item categorises for clarity and consistency.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris
